I did originally enjoy discovering the tech tree. I suppose it wouldn't matter if the old tech tree were revealed since most of have done it at least once, but since we're getting a new tech tree...

So I can predict two obvious ways mods can be broken by this (there's probably a lot more of them).

(This is more of a "what to watch out for when using un-maintained mods" - mods that don't get any new releases after 1.0 because they aren't being actively worked on anymore):

1 - There is currently a single API call for setting a new fixed loading distance. This new system sounds a bit more complex and that API call sounds likely to change.

2 - Any change to the tech tree is likely to require old parts configs to need an edit, as the tech tree nodes might change names and the node the part belongs in might not be called that anymore.

2. I guess you missed the devnote few weeks ago? IIRC HarvesteR said the new tech tree system no longer modify any cfg of part, it was configurable through a separated cfg file.

Glad to see another set of devnotes, and normally I'm not a fan of adding features at the last minute, but the few that made the last-minute list are basically polish and will be nice additions to the game. I'm glad they're slipping them in before experimentals so they'll be tested.

I really like the idea of all the nodes being visible from the start, and I'm very excited that they're finally (after all these updates) doing a comprehensive balance pass on the tech tree. I'm looking forward to trying out those tech tree modding tools after the release, editing config files by hand is not fun. New parts are always nice, especially when they have shiny new models and textures from talented modders like Porkjet.

The increase (and easily adjustable) physics range is also a nice improvement, as many others have said the current physics bubble is a bit small, especially for in atmosphere where things will be deleted from the game if you get too far away. A custom mouse cursor is a neat idea, my only request is to provide the option to use OS cursor and a way to easily use user-created custom cursors.

It will be interesting to see what those "exciting partnerships" are (hopefully not another Curse or Eucl3d, those were kind of disappointing honestly). I'm hoping for the best here.

Overall, glad to see that the team is in full beta mode now, the main systems appear to be in place so now it's getting down to balance and polish in preparation for experimentals.

If you do a proper gravity turn (and if the aero update is what I think it will be) then you should never be dropping boosters while over KSC. Also, you can get 22km away from a booster pretty quick. I would be surprised if most of my rockets had to worry about the boosters hitting the ground before getting out of the 22.5km window.

My first stages typically separate right around the 10km mark - so yes, I'd definitely have to strap parachutes to them (and deploy them on separation) to get out of the 22.5km bubble first.

(Since I use StageRecovery, I already put parachutes on my boosters.)

The second stage is not as big of an issue because I'm going 400-800 m/s by that point and am above 40-50km.

My guess is that this is more for "deploy unmanned probe on surface of X" type things where you use a plane to drop probes.

My first stages typically separate right around the 10km mark
You should be plenty downrange by then, and all of the dropped items should have plenty of horizontal velocity to carry them far out to sea. If the new aero is anything like FAR you'll want to start your gravity turn somewhere around 75~80m/s. Starting at 10km up will be just ... terrible.

Felipe (HarvesteR): ...

Dynamic physics bubble and visible tech tree: Relatively small changes, but they are going to be so much nicer to use

How are those floating point errors with that 22.5 load distance? ... And it makes me wonder if the 64bit client can better handle that.

64-bit client *should* make no difference to my knowledge. Memory addressing limitations are different to variable typing, 32-bit .exe handles single (32 bits of data) and double (64 bits of data) precision floating point numbers (numbers with fractional components eg. 3.14159, 1.5, -0.001). This does not change between compilers. What does have an effect is making sure that floating point calculations use double precision format whenever possible, but that's down to the programmer.

Regardless, in this case the difference is marginal. At 22500 meters, the precision would be approximately 2mm for a single precision output (assuming my math is correct). That will of course get notably larger if intermediate calculations are also single precision (because rounding intermediate calculations always leads to fun...)

Yes, but also even if you DID fire straight up to 10km and drop your boosters, there is NO WAY they'd get to the ground before you were 22.5km from that ground.

At 10km, you're heading upward at about 260m/s (if you're doing it right). you drop your boosters and they continue to go up at that speed, losing probably 10-20m/s every second (I didn't do the math, I'm just guessing based on the fact that you're going terminal velocity). So it should take them 20-30 seconds to slow down, peak out, and then start falling again, and another 20-30 seconds to fall back down to 10km. THEN they start falling toward the ground. In that minute or so, you're well over 500m/s and maybe scratching 1000m/s And you're probably 20km away or so.

Going sideways actually makes it a bit EASIER to keep the boosters in your physics bubble, but the second those chutes deploy they fall behind, and if you're nearing orbital velocity at that time (2km/s plus) you'll be out of their physics range in 10-20 seconds.

tl;dr 22.5km is not as far as you think it is when you're going as fast as you do during typical first separation.

64-bit client *should* make no difference to my knowledge.

Sure? The multithreading should help - while one vessels physics has to stay on one thread, another loaded vessels physics can be on another, resulting in less lag with multple loaded vessels - something likely to occur with a 22.5km loading distance.

Talking of that, it mentions the distance changes based on situation. Could someone expand on that? 22.5km suborbital in atmosphere, what about in space (orbiting and suborbital)? It's great stuff and a nice unexpected surprise, I'm just being greedy and asking for more info about it

Good stuff on the tech tree - I was forever alt-tabbing away to a picture of the full tree in Chrome to see what nodes are where. Good stuff!
I just wish they'd make it so that any part with a parachute (or a probe core) would be immune to disappearing outside the bubble.

Honestly, I think they should just simulate anything that falls in atmosphere anyway. Based on experience, the only times you really encounter this are on launch (jettisoned early stages), reentry (service modules, heat shields, etc), or when you are still well within Kerbin SOI (leaving objects on am unstable orbit shortly after launch). In any of these cases, it is unlikely that you would ever have more than a single digit number of objects in the atmosphere, and even then not for a very long time. If you throw in a configuration bar which allows for you to set the maximum number of objects you want to simulate aerodynamics for at any one time, I think it would become quite manageable for the CPU. This would finally allow us to have proper part recovery as well!

Nice! get well Kasper!

Multi threading has nothing to do with the amount of memory an application can address... (and my comment was specifically directed at the effects of floating point precision, which also has nothing to do with multi-threading)

However, It would be most interesting if the current vessel (and its components and debris) would have a much larger bubble - until that is you decide to switch vessels. As which point the system should prompt you that changing vessels at this time will reset the physics bubble to 22.5) So if you proceed then any objects in the atmosphere would likely be deleted and objects in space would unload.

Which this approach, the number of loaded objects should be low (if you build a Kessler bomb then its another question) and there is no doubt that components will impact the surface during any phase of an ascent.
